The objects cast shadows A, B, C, and D, which are positioned directly below the objects, indicating a light source above them.
When the light source moves backward (away from the objects), the angle of incidence changes, affecting both the position and size of the shadows.
As the light source moves backward, the shadows will shift forward on the ground, appearing to move toward the objects due to the light rays coming from a farther position.
The shadows will become larger as the light source moves backward because the angle of the light rays relative to the ground decreases, causing the shadows to stretch out more.
The shadow of Object A (cylindrical object) will become larger and move forward, elongating in the direction of the light source.
The shadow of Object B (irregularly shaped object) will enlarge and move forward, following the same principle as Object A.
The shadow of Object C (rectangular block) will enlarge and move forward, similar to the other objects.
The shadow of Object D (paper airplane) will enlarge and move forward, following the same pattern as the other objects.
When the light source moves backward above the objects, the shadows (A, B, C, and D) will move forward on the ground, closer to the objects, and increase in size.
